statement.text: Changes in net working capital (NWC) are cash flows in NPV analysis: increases in NWC represent cash outflows (investment), while decreases represent cash inflows. At project end, working capital is typically recovered.
statement.formal: ΔCF from NWC = -ΔNWC = -(ΔCA - ΔCL), where CA is current assets, CL is current liabilities

explanation.intuition: When a business grows, it needs more inventory and gives more credit to customers. This ties up cash - money sitting in a warehouse or owed by customers isn't available for other uses. NPV analysis must capture this investment.
explanation.key_insight: Working capital is an investment that typically reverses at project end. A project requiring $1M in NWC at start will likely recover that $1M when it concludes as inventory is sold and receivables collected.
explanation.technical_details: Net working capital = Current Assets - Current Liabilities. For NPV, focus on operating working capital: Inventory + Accounts Receivable - Accounts Payable. Cash holdings are typically excluded as they're part of treasury management.
common_misconceptions: Working capital is only an initial investment - it changes year-to-year with sales growth
Working capital costs nothing - it has opportunity cost (tied-up capital earns nothing)
Negative working capital is always bad - it can be efficient (e.g., retail) and reduces investment

definitions_glossary.cash_conversion_cycle: Time between paying for inputs and collecting from customers
definitions_glossary.working_capital_recovery: Return of NWC investment at project end
